problem:
If $\begin{vmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{vmatrix} = 5,$ then find
\[\begin{vmatrix} a - c & b - d \\ c & d \end{vmatrix}.\]
solution:
Since $\begin{vmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{vmatrix} = 5,$ $ad - bc = 5.$  Then
\[\begin{vmatrix} a - c & b - d \\ c & d \end{vmatrix} = (a - c)d - (b - d)c = ad - bc = \boxed{5}.\](Why does this make sense geometrically?)
socratic_questions:
1. Can you describe the first step in finding the determinant of the matrix $\begin{vmatrix} a - c & b - d \\ c & d \end{vmatrix}$?
2. What is the significance of the determinant $\begin{vmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{vmatrix}$ being equal to 5 in relation to the given matrix?
3. How does the determinant change when we subtract $c$ from $a$ and $d$ from $b$ in the given matrix?
4. Can you explain why the equation $(a - c)d - (b - d)c$ is equal to the determinant of the given matrix?
5. What is the geometric interpretation of the determinant of a matrix?
6. In general, what properties or transformations affect the determinant of a matrix?
7. Can you think of any other examples where a similar thought process and steps can be used to determine the determinant of a matrix?
